title: If, during my chapter 7 case, my income increases but is still below the median, will it cause any problems?
question: I would like to try to get a better paying job, and am wondering if this is something I could do before the case is discharged, or if I would have to wait.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
As Robert points out, if you get the job after the bankruptcy is filed, non-issue.

The only caveat is whether the job offer was intentionally delayed so as to occur after the bankruptcy is filed so the debtor could qualify for chapter 7 bankruptcy. That doesn't sound like your scenario.

Probably nothing you should worry about. The means test, etc all look to income before you file. There may be a good faith argument if you intentionally made less until after your bankruptcy, but that doesn't appear to be an issue here.

Good luck!

Generally speaking, if you get a higher paying job after the bankruptcy petition has been FILED, it will not change anything, especially if you are still below the median. The income used, for means test purposes, is the six months leading up to FILING, not DISCHARGE. If your income changes before filing, then the schedules will have to be amended, but it still should not change anything, assuming you are still below median income. If you have any questions, let a bankruptcy attorney assist you and review the specifics of your case.
